bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kêtahtawê êsah ôtênaw ê-misâk . Once upon a time there was a large town.

êkwah pêyak awa kicimâkisiwi-wêmiscikôsîs ê-papâmohtêt mânah ôtênâhk , kêkway ê-wîh-kakwê-miskahk ta-mîcit . And a certain poor little French boy there was, who used to walk about the town, trying to find something to eat. LB on {kicimâkisiwi-wêmiscikôsîs}: This word here, and {môniyâw}: “Englishman,” below, probably are intended merely as “white man.”

kêtahtawê êh-kîwêt , êh-tipiskâyik , mêkwâc êh-ay-apit , kâ-pîhtokêyit môniyâsah , tâpiskôc okimâw êh-sîhôwit . Then at one time, as he came home after dark, while he was there in his house, in came an Englishman who was dressed like a lord.
êkwêyâk ê-kiskêyihtamân êh-pimâtisiyin , itik . I have only just found out that you are alive,” he told him.

nîtim , itik ôhi môniyâsah ,
nikosisinaw ka-pakitinamawin cî ê-wîh-ôhpikihak ? “Sister-in-law,” that Englishman said to her, “will you give me our boy to bring up?”
êhag , itwêw . “Yes,” she answered.
mistahi sôniyâwah miyik . He gave her much money.
êkosi sipwêhtahêw nâpêsisah . So he took the boy away with him.
wâhyaw itohtêwak misi-waciy ; êkotêh takosinwak wacîhk . Far off they came to a great mountain; they arrived there at the mountain.
êkwah asiniy ê-misikitiyit yôhtênêw . Then he removed a large rock from an opening.
nâpêsis êwakô êkotah pîhtokêw . The boy went in there.
mitoni wanitipiskâyiw ; apisîs pikô wâsaskocêsiyiw . It was very dark; there was only a faint light.
êkos îsi kipahok ; kipaham . Then the other closed the door on him.

seg.q: kahni pêtâ nêma , nâpêsis , nêma wâsaskotênikan !
seg.gloss: “Just you bring that thing over there, boy that lamp!”

p.seg: êkwah otinam nâpêsis . The boy took it.
êkwah itohtêw iskwâhtêmihk . He went to the door.
nîkân miyin wâsaskotênikan ! itêw nâpêsisah . first give me the lamp!” he said to the boy.

namoya , itwêw nâpêsis ;
osâm ka-kipahon . “No,” said the boy; “You will lock me in.”

êkosi ,
kîpah pêtây ! Then, “Hurry up and hand it to me!”
piyis kisiwâsiw môniyâs awa . At last that Englishman got angry.
kipahwêw wâtihk nâpêsisah . He locked the boy in the cave.
êkwah mâh-mâtôw nâpêsis . [no translation]
papâmitâcimôw pikw îtêh wâtihkânihk . [no translation]
nama kêkway wâpahtam . He could not see anything.
kêtahtawê yâyîhtitâw ocihcîs , kâ-poscipayiyit âhcanisah . Presently he rubbed his hand and found that a ring had slipped on his finger.

kêkway , kâ-tipêyimiyan ? itik ôh âhcanisah . “What is it, you who are my master?” the ring asked him. LB: In part the genies which are attached to the ring and the lamp are distinct from these objects, but in part the informant, more in accord with Cree views, does not distinguish them.

omis îtwê :
nikotwâsik iskwâhtêm , pâskihtêpayih ! itwê , nâpêsis , itik . “Speak thus: ‘Six door, go open!’ Say that, boy,” it told him.

êkwah nâpêsis ,
nikotwâsik iskwâhtêm , pâskihtêpayih ! Then the boy, “Six door, go open!”
êkosi yôhtêpayiyiw . Thereupon it opened.
wayawîw nâpêsis . The boy went out.
wâsaskotênikan pêyak ayâw . He had a lamp.

êkw âhcanisah tahkih êyakonih pîkiskwâtikôw . And that ring always talked to him. LB: Verb-form with inanimate actor, although {ahcânis}: “ring,” is of animate gender; in fact, even an inanimate noun in such a connexion would ordinarily be used in animate gender.
êkwah sipwêhtêw , êh-kîwêt . Then he went from there, homeward.
êkwah êh-takosihk wîkiwâhk , âcimostawêw okâwiyah . When he reached home, he told his mother the tale.
êkwah pêtâ kîkway ; nika-kâsîhên niwâsiskotênikan , itêw . “Now give me something to wipe off my lamp,” he told her. LB on {kîkway}: Meaning “a rag” - temporary word-avoidance.
êkwah miyik ; kâsîham . She gave him something; he wiped it.
kêkway nitawêyihtaman , kâ-tipêyimiyan ? itik mistâpêwah pêyak . “What do you desire, you who are my master?” a giant asked him.
sêkihik , wâsiskotênikanihk êy-ohci-wayawiyit . He frightened him, coming out of the lamp.
niwaskâhikan t-ôsîhtâyan êh-miywâsik mistahi , itêw . “That you build me a very fine house,” he told him.
ahag , itik . “Very well,” said the other to him.
êkwah êh-nipâcik , âsay kîsihtâyiwa , mistah ê-miywâsiniyik . Then while they slept he had already finished it, and very beautiful it was.
sâkihtam wâsiskotênikan . The boy took good care of the lamp.

seg.q: pikô kêkway nêtawêyihtamani , ka-kâsîhên oma wâsaskotênikan , êkwah ahcânis .
seg.gloss: “Whenever you desire no matter what, you will rub this lamp and ring.

seg.q: pikw îtê nk-âyân ; itwêyanih êkotêh nik-âyân .
seg.gloss: No matter where I am, when you bid it, I shall be there.

p.seg: nama kêkway ka-pwâtawihtân , itik nâpêsis awa . You will fail of nothing,” he said to the boy.
kêtahtawê êh-ay-apicik , awa maci-môniyâs pihkwah otinam ; Then at one time, as they dwelt there, that evil Englishman took some ashes;
miscikowacisihk asiwatâw . he put them into a little woodenbox.

kiskêyihtam , êkot êh-masinahikêhk pihkohk , nâpêsisah êh-pimâtisiyit , êh-ayâyit animah kâ-mantôwaniyik wâsaskotênikan . From the pattern of the ashes there he saw that the boy was alive and that he had that magic lamp.

êkwah êyakonih sipwêhtatâw , itah têkosihkih , êh-mâyâtahkih wâsaskotênikanah ê-wîh-atâwêt , mîskoc êh-miywâsiniyik êh-mêkit . he went off with them, to buy worthless lamps wherever he came, giving good lamps in return.
piyis otihtêw nâpêsisah . At last he came to the boy.
pêyakwapiw nôtokêsiw . The old woman was alone at home.

kakwêcimêw ,
namoya cî kêkway kitayân wâsaskotênikan êh-mâyâtahk ? He asked her, “Haven't you perhaps some worthless old lamp?

seg.gloss: I will give you a good one for it.”

p.seg:
êkwah ,
pêyak astêw ôtah ; ka-miyitin , itêw nôtokêw . Then, “There is one here; I will give it to you,” said the old woman to him.
êkwah nitonam ; miskam ; miyêw . She sought it; she found it; she gave it to him.
mîskoc miyik êh-miywâsiniyik . In return he gave her a good one.
êyokô kâ-nitawêyihtamân , itêw awa maci-kimotisk . “This is what I want,” said the evil thief to her.
êkwah nâpêsis awa namoya âpiw ; kîh-nakatam owâsaskotênikan kâ-manitôwaniyik . Now the boy was not at home; he had left his magic lamp.
êkwah takosin . Then he arrived.

kakwêcimêw okâwiyah ,
tâniwê animah niwâsiskotênikan ? He asked his mother, “Where is that lamp of mine?”

nikosis , itik ,
êh-miywâsik mîskoc kkîh-miyikawinânaw , êh-atâmikawiyahk êwakôw kiwâsaskotênikan , itêw . “My son,” she told him, “we have been given a good one in trade for that lamp of yours.”
kisiwâsiw nâpêsis . The boy was angry.
êwakôw wâtihkânihk kâ-kîh-kwêstêwêpinit , kâ-wayêsimisk , itêw okâwiyah . This person was the one who threw me into the cave, this person who has cheated you,” he told his mother.
êkwah sipwêhtêw nâpêsis . Then the boy went away.
kêtahtawê êh-pa-pmohtêt , êh-tipiskâyik , npâw . Presently, as he walked along and night fell, he went to sleep.

êh-pêkopayit , êh-waskawît ,
kîkway , kâ-tipêyimiyan , êh-ntawêyihtaman ? itik ohcahcanisah êh-yâyisimât . When he awoke, as he stirred, “What is it you desire, you who are my master?” he was asked by his ring, which he had rubbed.
tântê k-âyât kâ-kimotamawit niwâsskotênikan , êkotêh nik-âyân , itêw . “Wherever he is who stole my lamp from me, there let me be,” he told it.
êhag , itik . “Very well,” it said to him.
êh-nipât , kîhtwâm êh-pêkopayit , kisiwâk waskâhikan ayâyiw . When he went to sleep and again woke up, there was a house close by.

êkwah ,
tânisiy êkwah kê-tôtamân ? têyihtam . Then, “What shall I do now?” he thought.
êkwah wâpamêw ê-sipwêhtêyit . Then he saw the other depart.
êkwah itohtêw . Thereupon he went there.
êkwah ispacâw wâskahikanihk êh-tâskipayiyit mistikwah , êkotah kâsôw . then in a crack of a timber in the roof of the house he hid.
êkwah wâpamêw oskinîkiskwêwah êkotah êh-ayâyit . He saw a young woman who was there.
kapê-tipisk êkotah ayâw , êh-pêhât ta-nipâyit . He stayed all night, waiting for the other to sleep.
piyis nipâw awa kimotisk . At last the thief went to sleep.
êkwah ocâhcanisah kâsîhwêw . Then he rubbed his ring.
kîkway êh-ntawêyihtaman , kâ-tipêyimiyan ? itik . “What is it you desire, you who are my master?” it asked him.

seg.q: awah kâ-kîh-kimotamawit wâsaskotênikan âkamihk kihcikamîhk ka-ntawih-pakitinâw .
seg.gloss: “This person who stole my lamp from me you will go place across the sea.

p.seg: niwâsaskotênikan ka-nakatên , itêw . My lamp you will leave behind.” he told it.
êhag , itik . “Very well,” it answered him.
êkwah wiyah otinam wâsaskotênikan kâ-manitôwaniyik . Then he took the magic lamp.
nîkinâhk nik-âyân ! itwêw nâpêsis . “Let me be in our own house!” said the boy.
êkotêh awah êkwah mînah kâkikê pimiwitâw oswâsaskotênikan ; nama wîhkâc nakatam . There he then always carried his lamp with him; he never left it.
kêtahtawê mînah kâ-papâmohtêt awa kimotisk , êh-papâ-atâwâkêt ê-sôniyâwiyikih sakâpîhkânisah . Presently, there was that thief going about again, selling golden chains.
pîhtokêw êkotah nâpêsisah owâskâhikaniyihk . He entered the boy's house.
nôtokêsiw pêyakwapiw . The old woman was alone in the house.
mâskôc ôma ayâyiki , wâwîs mistahi tah-okimâwiw kikosis , itik ; “Perhaps if this thing is here, your son will become an even greater man,” he told her;

seg.gloss: “Here in the centre of the house do you hang it up;
and inside it do you put a stone heart; put it inside.
seg.note: LB on {k-âsiwatân}: {asiwatâw}: “he puts it inside” (as into a box or bag), but we are not told into what. Immediately below the word is used in a common specialized meaning, “he puts it into his bag, bosom-fold, pocket”; farther on, similarly, the corresponding verb with animate object, {asiwahêw}, specialized: “bring (animal) under shelter.”

seg.gloss: Thus will your house be very beautiful.”

p.seg: atâmêw nôtokêsiw . The old woman bought it.
êkosi sipwêhtêw awa kimotisk . Then the thief went away.
êkwah awah takosin nâpêsis . Then the boy arrived.

êkwah nôtokêw ,
nikosis , itêw ,
ntatâwân omah k-âkotêk êkotah , t-âsiwatâyan asinîwi-mitêh . Then the old woman said to him, “My son, I have bought the stone heart that hangs there so that you may carry it about with you.”
êkwah nâpêsis miywêyihtam . Then the boy liked it.
êkwah êh-tipiskâyik kâsîham wâsaskotênikan . When night came, he rubbed the lamp.

kêkway êh-ntawêyihtaman ? itik owâsaskotênikan . “What do you want?” his lamp asked him. LB: Either the nouns should be made animate obviative (ending {-ah}), or the preceding verb given inanimate actor ({itikôw}).
oma k-âkotêk êôkotah k-âsiwatêk asiniwi-mitêh , itik . “The stone heart that is inside the thing which hangs there,” he answered.
kisiwâsiw sêmâk . At once he grew angry.
kêkâc kinipahitin ; ntêh animah , itik awa nâpêsis ; “I could easily kill you; that is my heart,” it said to the boy;

ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahisk an , îtik . “It was certainly that he wanted to kill you,” it told him. LB: For {anih itik}; the sandhi is often carried from a quotation over to the verbs of saying, {itêw} (transitive), {itwêw} (intransitive).
êkosi namoya tâpwêhtawêw . So he did not do what the other had told him.
kîtahtawê kâ-takosiniyit maskihkîw-iyiniwah . Presently there arrived a physician.
êh-miyosit maskihkîwiyiniw , itâw . “An excellent physician,” was said of him.
âhkosiw a nâpêsis . The boy was ill. CHECK “a”

êyôkw ânah , itik ,
ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahisk ; “That is the one,” the other told him, “who means to kill you;

seg.gloss: he will come to see you;

p.seg: nipahâhkan , itik . then do you kill him” he was told by the other.
êkwah pê-ntawâpamik . Soon he came to see him.
nipêwinihk ê-pimisihk môhkoman tahkonam . He held a knife as he lay in his bed.
kitâhkosin ? itik . “Are you sick?” the other asked him.
êhag , itêw . “Yes,” he told him.
êkwah ôtah êh-pê-nawakiyit , tahkamêw ; nipahêw . Then, when the other leaned over, he stabbed him and killed him.
â , tânêhki ? maskihkîw-iyiniw kinipahâw ! itik okâwiyah . “Dear me, what are you doing? You have killed the physician!” his mother said to him.
â , namoya maskihkîw-iyiniw ! itêw ; “Oh, he was no physician!” he told her;

seg.gloss: “Because he meant to kill me is why I killed him.”

p.seg: pikw îtah ocasiwacikaniyihk môhkomân miskamwak , mîn îsawêsk êh-pimiwitâyit , mînah piscipôwin , ê-kî-wîh-piscipohikot awa nâpêsis . in his various pockets they found a knife and a sword which he carried with him, and poison with which he had meant to poison the boy.
êkwah ay-ayâw . Then he dwelt there.
kêtahtawê nîpâtipisk kâ-takosiniyit mitâtaht nâpêwah , sôsôwatimwah êh-nâ-nayahcikêyit . Then, at one time, in the darkness of night there arrived ten men who had donkeys as their beasts of burden.
pêyak pîhtokêyiwa . One of them entered the house.
nama wiya cî nika-kîh-kapêsinân ? itik . “May we camp here for the night?” he asked him.
kapêsik ; kitêmiwâwak asiwahihkok , itêw . “Yes, do; and bring your beasts inside,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “No; they can stand where they are.”

p.seg: êkosi sakahpitêwak otêmiwâwah . Accordingly, they tied up their beasts.
êkwah êkotah oskinîkiskwêw paminawasôw ; asamêw . Then the young woman prepared a meal; she gave them food.
êkwah êh-kîsi-mîcisôwiht , kâsîhiyâkanêw . When her guests had eaten, she washed the dishes.

êkwah ê-ntawi-wêpinahk kâsîhiyâkanâpoy , itohtêw ôhi sôsôwatimwah , kâ-pêhtahk ,
âsay cî ? êh-itikot , kîmôc ê-pîkiskwêyit . When she went to pour out the dishwater, she went to where the donkeys were, and there she heard someone say to her in a whisper, “Is it time?”

namoya , itêw ;
kêkâc , itêw . “No,” she answered; “Soon.”
ôhi sôsôwatimwah kâ-nayômâcik kimotiskah mahkahkohk . Those donkeys were carrying none other than robbers in boxes.
pîhtokêw êkwah oskinîkiskwêw . Then the young woman entered the house.
êkwah kisâkamisam nipiy ; mistahi mitonih sîsîpaskihkohk sîkinam . She heated some water; she poured a great amount of it into a kettle with a spout.
êkwah wayawîhtitâw . Then she took it out of the house.
êkwah yôhtênam mahkahk . Then she opened a box.
âsay cî ? itik . “Is it time?” the man asked her.
êhag , itêw . “Yes,” she told him.
pîhci-sîkinam nipiy mahkahkohk ; nipahêw ôhi kimotiskah . She poured the water into the box; she killed that robber.
nipahîhkâswêw kahkiyaw . She scalded them all to death.
êkwah pîhtokêw ; âmaciwêw êkwah , otôkimâmah êh-ntawâpamât . Then she went into the house; she went upstairs to see her master.
pêyak ôhi êkotah apiyiwah kêyâpic . One of the others was still there.

ntôkimâm , itêw ,
kayâs mânah ê-nihtâ-nôtinikêyân , itêw ,
kayâs tânsi ê-kîh-tôtamân ka-kitâpaminâwâw .
“My lord,” she said to her master, “in former time I used to fight and you shall now see how I did, in former time.

seg.gloss: I shall deck myself as for the fight; that is the way I shall dress.”

p.seg: tâpwêh ! itêw awa otôskinîkiskwêmah . “Do indeed!” he told his young handmaid.
êkwah nîhtaciwêw oskinîkiskwêw ; nta-wawêyîw . Then the young woman went downstairs; she went and dressed.
êkwah pê-âmaciwêw . Then she came upstairs.
isawisk tahkonam êkwah môhkomân . She held a sword and a knife.
kayâs êkosi ê-kîh-isîhoyâhk , kâ-nôtinikêyâhk , itêw . “In former times this was the way we dressed when we fought,” she told them.
êkwah êkotah pâh-pimohtêw , pikw îsi êh-tôtahk . Then she walked about there, acting in various ways.
kêtahtawê nâpêwah ôhi kîskwêwêpahwêw . Suddenly she knocked that man out of his senses.
tâpwê namoya kwayask kitôtên , êh-kiyôkêt okimâw êh-nipahat ! itik otôkimâmah . “Truly you are not doing right, to kill this lord who is our guest!” her master said to her.

seg.q: kîspin êkâh kîh-nipahak , âpihtâ-tipiskâk âsay kah-nipahik ;
seg.gloss: “If I had not killed him, by midnight he would have killed you;

p.seg: ê-wîh-nipahisk , k-ôh-pêy-iytohtêt , itik ; in order to kill you was why he came here,” she told him;
pikw îtah oskotâkâhk omaskimotisihk otasikânihk , pikw îtah ka-miskên môhkomânah , itik . Everywhere in his coat, in his pockets, in his stockings, everywhere you will find knives,” she told him.
tâpwêh ntonikêw ; [no translation] oskotâkayihk otasikaniyihk mihcêt môhkomânah miskam . [no translation]
êkwah tâpw ês ânih kipimâcihin ! itik otôkimâmah . “Now really you have saved my life!” her master said to her.
ntawi-pakastawêhwêwak kahkiyaw mitâtaht kimotiskah . they went and threw all ten of the robbers into the water.
êkosi wiy êwôkô pêyak âtayôhkêwin nikîsihtân . And so I have finished this one sacred story.
